text:
(1) Sheepshead Bay, east from the "Bridge" at East 19th Street. Emmons Ave., parallels the water on the left. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, at another angle. April 2, 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - East 19th Street.

text:

title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - East 19th Street.

text:
(1)
East 19th Street, west side, at, adjoining and north of Emmons Ave. The view of the 3-story frame building has changed; in 1934 stores were built in front and the entrance to the Grill is on East 19th Street.

July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing at the N.E. corner the Sheepshead Bay house in 1857; the John McMahon Hotel in 1873. This hotel was leased in December 1924 by the McMahon Estate to the Laudne Holding Company (Lundy Bros.) who converted it into quarters for waiters employed in the Lundy Restaurant. December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, when it was known as the Tamaqua Yacht Club.
January 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)

Sheepshead Bay (Brooklyn): Viewing north toward Emmons Avenue, between East 19th Street (left) and Kenmore Place, seen from the bridge across the Bay which connects Emmons Avenue with Manhattan Beach. The houses on the left were later demolished and replaced with Lundy's Restaurant.

April 2, 1924

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

(2)

The same location, years later. The boatmen are selling fish from "Pilot II."

July 13, 1933

P. L. Sperr

(3)

Lundy Brothers Restaurant, on the site of the frame houses seen in views 1 and 2.

August 1, 1935

P. L. Sperr
title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - [Lundy Brothers Restaurant.]

text:
Emmons Ave., north side, at, adjoining and east of East 19th Street. The 3-story frame building in the foreground, is still standing. All the other buildings were razed to make way for the New Lundy Restaurant in 1934.

July 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Sheepshead Bay (Brooklyn): The bridge over the Bay which connects Emmons Avenue, at East 19th Street, with Manhattan Beach.

July 13, 1933

P. L. Sperr

(2)

A pier, off Emmons Avenue at East 19th Street, designated as Pier 12.

July 8, 1936

P. L. Sperr

(3)

A fishing pier, off Emmons Avenue, at East 21st Street.

P. L. Sperr

August 14, 1937
title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - [Emmons Avenue - Between 19th and 21st Streets (East) - Pier 12.]

title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - [Emmons Avenue - Between 19th and 21st Streets (East) - Pier 12.]

text:
Sheepshead Bay: A view of the north side of the Bay, between Sheepshead Bay Road (left) and Dooley Lane (right), showing prominently the pedestrian bridge at the foot of East 19th Street, that connects the Sheepshead Bay area to Manhattan Beach. East of same, on the north side of Emmons Ave., is the new Lundy Brothers Restaurant Building, standing on the old Mahon property. This structure was erected in 1935 and replaced the older one that stood on the south side of the Ave. at the waters edge and was demolished as part of the new waterfront development. This is a panoramic set of two views. August 1, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

E6 Neg. # 3946
E7 Neg. # 3945
title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - between Sheepshead Road and Dooley Lane.

text:
Sheepshead Bay, northeastward from the bridge at East 19th Street, showing Emmons Ave. at the left. In the foreground are a group of fishing boats. Note the old piers which were demolished by the City of New York and replaced by modern ones.
August 1, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, from another angle. At the right is the old Lundy Restaurant razed early in 1935. In the left foreground, the building having the sign "sea food" was razed in 1934 to make way for Lundy's new restaurant.
July 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, showing the "Flying D" coming to dock after a day at the fishing banks.
July 13, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - East 19th Street - [Flying "D" - Lundy Brothers Restaurant.]

text:
East 19th Street, west side, north from the N.W. corner of Emmons Ave. One of the many parking spaces in Sheepshead Bay.

August 1, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
